leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.21] r 42.21 Security for costs (cf SCR Part 53, rules 2, 3, 4 and 5; DCR Part 40, rule 1; LCR Part 31, rule 11A, Part 31A, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Security for costs (cf SCR Part 53, rules 2, 3, 4 and 5; DCR Part 40, rule 1; LCR Part 31, rule 11A, Part 31A, rule 11)

p.text: If, in any proceedings, it appears to the court on the application of a defendant:
that a plaintiff is ordinarily resident outside New South Wales, or

that the address of a plaintiff is not stated or is mis-stated in his or her originating process, and there is reason to believe that the failure to state an address or the mis-statement of the address was made with intention to deceive, or

that, after the commencement of the proceedings, a plaintiff has changed his or her address, and there is reason to believe that the change was made by the plaintiff with a view to avoiding the consequences of the proceedings, or
that there is reason to believe that a plaintiff, being a corporation, will be unable to pay the costs of the defendant if ordered to do so, or

that a plaintiff is suing, not for his or her own benefit, but for the benefit of some other person and there is reason to believe that the plaintiff will be unable to pay the costs of the defendant if ordered to do so,

the court may order the plaintiff to give such security as the court thinks fit, in such manner as the court directs, for the defendant’s costs of the proceedings and that the proceedings be stayed until the security is given.
Security for costs is to be given in such manner, at such time and on such terms (if any) as the court may by order direct.
If the plaintiff fails to comply with an order under this rule, the court may order that the proceeding on the plaintiff’s claim for relief in the proceedings be dismissed.
This rule does not affect the provisions of any Act under which the court may require security for costs to be given.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[50], effective 15 August 2005]
[r 42.21 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[49], effective 15 August 2005]

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.21(1).

The fundamental purpose of the power to order security for costs is to secure justice between the parties — principally by ensuring that unsuccessful proceedings do not occasion injustice to defendants. This rule confers a wide discretion that is to be exercised having regard to all the circumstances of the particular case. The discretion is not restricted by any special rules and should not be circumscribed by an inflexible approach to burden of proof issues. Accordingly, there is no rule that an order for security ought be made merely because the grounds set out in r 42.21(1) have been established: Barton v Minister for Foreign Affairs (1984) 2Â FCR 463; 54 ALR 586; Adams v Population Services International (A'asia) Ltd (SC(NSW), O'BrienÂ CJ in CD, S17831/1982, 27Â April 1984, unreported); cf Crozat v Brogden [1894] 2Â QB 30; Waters v Waters [1909] SASR 133; Kohn v Rinson & Stafford (Broad) Ltd [1948] 1Â KB 327; Hudson Strumpf-Fabrik GmbH v Bentley Engineering Co Ltd [1962] 2Â QB 587 at 589 and Demag-Lauchhammer v John Holland (Constructions) Pty Ltd [1966] 2 NSWR 3; (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 231Â .

level.toc-caption: [42.21.10] Relevant considerations in the exercise of the discretion

heading.title: Relevant considerations in the exercise of the discretion

p.text: The court's discretion to order security for costs both requires and permits account to be taken of a wide range of considerations. Many cases, such as Equity Access Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1989) ATPR Â¶40-972 at 50,365 and KP Cable Investments Pty Ltd v Meltglow Pty Ltd (1995) 56 FCR 189 at 197–8; 13 ACLC 437Â ; summarise factors relevant to the exercise of the discretion. Those factors include the following:

whether the plaintiff's claim is made in good faith and appears to be reasonably arguable: Lynnebry Pty Ltd v Farquhar Enterprises Pty Ltd (1977) 3 ACLR 133Â ; J & M O'Brien Enterprises Pty Ltd v Shell Co of Australia (1983) 7 ACLR 790Â ; compare Collignon Developments Pty Ltd v Wurth (1975) 1 ACLR 314Â . If the plaintiff’s claim appears reasonably arguable it is not appropriate to attempt a more detailed assessment of the prospects of success: Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2004) 208 ALR 564; [2004] NSWSC 664; BC200404777 at [37]–[39]Â . A defendant who admits the plaintiff's claim but asserts a cross-claim arising out of the same transaction, or a series of transactions, may obtain security for costs against the plaintiff: Demag-Lauchhammer v John Holland (Constructions) Pty Ltd [1966] 2 NSWR 3; (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 231Â ; Winterfield v Bradnum (1878) 3 QBD 324Â ; compare Motakov Ltd v Commercial Hardware Supplies Pty Ltd (1952) 70 WN (NSW) 64Â (where the cross-claim arose out of an independent transaction and an application for security for costs against the plaintiff was refused).

The status of the defendant, for example as an insurer of the plaintiff, is a relevant, but not decisive, consideration against the grant of security: Prime Forme Cutting Pty Ltd v Baltica General Insurance Co (1989) 8 ACLC 29Â ; Frankston Ambassador Pty Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1991) 9 ACLC 790Â ; Quichorn Pty Ltd (t/as Heidelberg Hotel) v Broad (VSC), Hayne J, 24 January 1994, unreported, BC9406622) — not following Irwin Alsop Services v Mercantile Mutual Insurance Co Ltd [1986] VR 61; (1985) 10 ACLR 176; (1986) 4 ACLC 110Â ;

whether the plaintiff's lack of funds has been caused or contributed to by the conduct of the defendant: Lynnebry Pty Ltd v Farquhar Enterprises Pty Ltd , above; O’Keefe v Seafresh Holdings Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1090; BC200909362Â (security refused); or has arisen from other circumstances: Newtons Travel Services Pty Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 556Â ; Amalgamated Mining Services Pty Ltd v Warman International Ltd (1988) 19 FCR 324; 88 ALR 63Â .
whether the plaintiff's proceedings are merely a defence against “self help” measures taken by the defendant: Heller Factors Pty Ltd v John Arnold's Surf Shop Pty Ltd (1979) 4 ACLR 492Â ;

whether the making of the order would unduly stultify the plaintiff's ability to pursue the proceedings: MA Productions Pty Ltd v Austarama Television Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 97Â ; Spiel v Commodity Brokers Australia Pty Ltd (1983) 8 ACLR 410Â ; Tradestock Pty Ltd v TNT (Management) Pty Ltd (1977) 14 ALR 52; 30 FLR 342 at 348Â ; 104 Alice Street Pty Ltd v Jabamak Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 162; BC200901609Â (application for further security dismissed); Bell Wholesale Co Ltd v Gates Export Corporation [1984] FCA 34; [1984] 2 FCR 1 at 4 (company bears the onus of establishing that an order for security would stultify the litigation); Pioneer Park Pty Ltd (in liq) v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (2007) 65 ACSR 383; [2007] NSWCA 344; BC200710441Â ; Dae Boong International Co Pty Ltd v Gray [2009] NSWCA 11; BC200900448 at [23]Â ff (security ordered in the absence of satisfaction that stultification was likely);

the extent to which it is reasonable to expect creditors or shareholders (or other persons financially involved in the conduct of the proceedings, for example, litigation funders) to make funds available to satisfy any order for security which is made: National Bank v Donald Export Trading Ltd [1980] 1 NZLR 97Â ; Drumdurno Pty Ltd v Braham (1982) 7 ACLR 131Â ; Bell Wholesale Co v Gates Export Corp (1983) 2 FCR 1; 52 ALR 176; Memutu Pty Ltd v Lissenden (1983) 8 ACLR 364Â ; Harpur v Ariadne Australia Ltd [1984] 2 Qd R 523 at 532; (1984) 8 ACLR 835 at 841–2Â (company principal agreeing to meet costs); Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2004) 208 ALR 564; [2004] NSWSC 664; BC200404777 at [78]–[79]Â (litigation funder — security ordered); Project 28 Pty Ltd v Barr [2005] NSWCA 240; BC200505224 at [115]–[116]Â (shareholders agreeing to meet costs liability); Jazabas Pty Ltd v Haddad (2007) 65 ACSR 276; [2007] NSWCA 291; BC200709159 at [74]Â (shareholders not providing formal undertaking to meet costs — security ordered);

the likelihood of a costs order being made at the conclusion of proceedings and the public interest nature of the litigation: Byron Shire Business for the Future Inc v Byron Shire Council and Holiday Villages (Byron Bay) Pty Ltd (1994) 83 LGERA 59Â ; KP Cable Investments Pty Ltd v Meltglow Pty Ltd (1995) 56 FCR 189; 13 ACLC 437; BC9507833Â .

The court does not set out to provide a complete indemnity to the defendant in respect of their costs: Brundza v Robbie & Co (No 2) (1952) 88 CLR 171 at 175; 27 ALJR 422Â . The court’s power is to require “sufficient security” and the court must also have regard to the effect of the order upon the plaintiff’s ability to continue the litigation. The court is not bound to accept the defendant’s estimate of the costs likely to be incurred: Parkinson & Co v Triplan Ltd [1973] QB 609 at 619Â ; MA Productions Pty Ltd v Austarama Television Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 97Â .

In determining the amount of security the court may act on the basis of a general estimate. This is particularly so where there are real difficulties in forming a reliable assessment of the likely costs: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1995) 134 ALR 187Â . In determining the appropriate amount of the security, the court will not generally make any assumption about the basis on which costs might be assessed: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1995) 134 ALR 187Â . The objective is not to provide the defendants with full indemnity against all eventualities: Bryan EÂ Fencott & Associates Pty Ltd v Eretta Pty Ltd (1987) 16 FCR 497Â . The court may initially order security to be given only for the costs of preparing the matter for hearing: APEP Pty Ltd v Smalley (1983) 8 ACLR 260Â ; Collignon Developments Pty Ltd v Wurth (1975) 1 ACLR 314Â ; see generally Procon Ltd v Provincial Building Co [1984] 2 All ER 368Â . The defendants may make further application at a later stage if they think it necessary to do so: Transocean Capital Pty Ltd v AFSIG Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 806; BC200606178 at [42]Â . It may be appropriate in the particular circumstances of an individual case, for security (in such amount as agreed or determined) to be ordered by stages. The parties may be asked to agree on a staged timetable for the provision of security: Sharjade v Darwinia Estate Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 708; BC200605732Â . If the parties cannot agree on the quantum of security, the court can make an order for reference to a referee: Sharjade v Darwinia Estate Pty Ltd, above.

An order for security for the costs of proceedings in the Court of Appeal may be made in “special circumstances”: UCPR r 51.50 . The requirement for “special circumstances” is satisfied if the Court of Appeal appellant/claimant has neither complied with, nor sought to stay, the judgment or order that is the subject of the appeal: Mazzei v Industrial Relations Commission of New South Wales (2000) 97 IR 457; [2000] NSWCA 104; BC200002010Â (appellant claiming prerogative relief in relation to the exercise of another court’s powers). See [51.50.5] .

It had been held in Holman v Dynabuild Pty Ltd [1975] 2 NSWLR 334Â that the present rule did not permit the court to make an order for security for costs in connection with arbitration proceedings. However, the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 sÂ 17J empowers the court to issue “interim measures” (as set out in sÂ 17 ) for the purposes of arbitration proceedings of the same kind that it could make in relation to proceedings in the court. Similar provisions in the previous legislation (Commercial Arbitration Act 1984) had been held to permit the making of orders for security for costs in arbitration proceedings: Johnson v Macri and Marcellino Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Cole J, 8 June 1990, unreported, BC9002978), and see also Alliance Petroleum Australia NL v Australian Gas Light Co (1983) 34 SASR 215; 48 ALR 69Â and Re Vassal Pty Ltd (1984) 2 ACLC 53Â .

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.21(1)(a), r 42.21(1)(d).
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1335(1).

Although s 117 of the Constitution prevents interstate residence from providing a basis for ordering security for costs against a natural person, it does not apply to a corporation: Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd v ARM Equipment Finance Pty Ltd (2001) 159 FLR 310; [2001] NSWSC 28; BC200100087 at [26]Â . Nevertheless, a corporation is a “person” for the purpose of the present rule: Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd v ARM Equipment Finance Pty Ltd (2001) 159 FLR 310; [2001] NSWSC 28; BC200100087 at [58], [59]Â . It follows that r 42.21(1)(a) affords a possible basis for ordering security against a corporation that was “resident” outside New South Wales. But the discretionary considerations about the appropriate amount of security in such a case (see [42.21.15] ) would mean that exceptional circumstances would be required before such an order is likely to be made. The other basis under which the present rule would permit security for costs to be ordered against a corporation is contained in r 42.21(1)(d) . The considerations relevant to an application under r 42.21(1)(d) are similar to the requirements under s 1335(1) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) — namely, that a corporate plaintiff will be unable to pay any costs awarded to the defendant: Fitzpatrick v Waterstreet (1995) 18 ACSR 694Â ; Lesvos Pty Ltd v Penrith Whitewater Stadium Ltd (2006) 58 ACSR 481; [2006] NSWSC 823; BC200606371Â .

In KPÂ Cable Investments Pty Ltd v Meltglow Pty Ltd (1995) 56 FCR 189; 13 ACLC 437Â , Beazley J set out seven considerations by which the Court should be guided on an application for security for costs. That approach was adopted in Asia Strategic Investment Alliances Ltd v HIH Casualty & General Insurance Ltd [1999] NSWSC 601; BC9903719Â (BerginÂ J). It has subsequently been frequently applied: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 744; BC200105623Â ; Thalanga Copper Mines Pty Ltd v Brandrill Ltd [2004] NSWSC 349Â ; Sharjade v Darwinia Estate Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 708; BC200605732Â ; Transocean Capital Pty Ltd v AFSIG Pty Ltd (2006) 202 FLR 270; [2006] NSWSC 806; BC200606178Â .

Section 57A of the Corporations Act 2001 defines “corporation” to include any body corporate (whether incorporated in New South Wales or elsewhere), a company (defined in s 9 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)), a recognised company (defined in s 9) and certain unincorporated bodies, formed outside New South Wales. Excluded from the definition of corporation are exempt public authorities (defined in s 9) and a corporation sole. Finally, in New South Wales the following exempt bodies are also excluded from the definition of corporation: (a) a body registered under the Co-Operations Act 1923; (b) a co-operative within the meaning of the Co-Operatives Act 1992; (c) a friendly society within the meaning of the Friendly Societies Act 1989; (d) bodies or companies exempted from compliance with s 61(1) of the Co-Operations Act 1923; and (e) bodies incorporated under the Associations Incorporation Act 1984. The decision in Co-operative Farmers’ & Graziers’ Direct Meat Supply Ltd v Smart [1977] VR 386Â precluding the obtaining of security for costs against a co-operative under the Companies Act 1961 would appear to remain good law under the present Corporations Law regime.

level.toc-caption: [42.21.40] Corporations — security ordered under sÂ 1335(1) of the Corporations Act 2001

heading.title: Corporations — security ordered under sÂ 1335(1) of the Corporations Act 2001

p.text: Section 1335 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) provides a statutory discretion to order security against a corporation that is likely to be unable to pay costs ordered in favour of the defendant. The section contrasts with the general rule that the poverty of a litigant is no ground for requiring security: Cowell v Taylor (1885) 31 Ch D 34Â ; Pearson v Naydler [1977] 3 All ER 531; [1977] 1 WLR 899 at 902Â ; Re Donnelly (1927) 44 WN (NSW) 72Â . Under s 1335, the power to order security is founded upon the likely inability of the corporate litigant to satisfy any order for costs made against it: Pacific Acceptance Corp Ltd v Forsyth (No 2) [1967] 2 NSWR 402 at 407; (1967) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 715 at 721Â . Nevertheless, there is no rule to the effect that an impecunious or insolvent company will be ordered to provide security except in special circumstances: Webster v Lampard (1993) 112 ALR 174; 67 ALJR 393Â per Toohey J. In Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd (1974) 1 ACLR 301 at 305Â Street CJ, after considering the conflicting views expressed in Sir Lindsay Parkinson & Co Ltd v Triplan [1973] 2 All ER 273Â , said that the discretion to order costs “could properly be regarded as ordinarily exercisable so as to protect a defendant sued by an impecunious company” so that there was a predisposition in favour of ordering security. Some subsequent cases have, however, treated these comments of Street CJ as obiter and declined to follow them on the basis that they place an unnecessary gloss on the wording of the statutory provision: MA Productions Pty Ltd v Austarama Television Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 97Â ; Heller Factors Pty Ltd v John Arnold’s Surf Shop Pty Ltd (1979) 4 ACLR 492Â ; Spiel v Commodity Brokers Australia Pty Ltd (1983) 8 ACLR 410Â ; Plaza Print Pty Ltd v South British Insurance Co Ltd (1984) 8 ACLR 797Â ; National Bank v Donald Export Trading Ltd [1980] 1 NZLR 97Â . These cases support the proposition that the discretion conferred by s 1335 is a general one and is in that sense unfettered: Caruso Australia Pty Ltd v Portec (Aust) Pty Ltd (1984) 8 ACLR 818Â ; Westralian Goldmines Ltd v Westralian Minerals and Drilling Pty Ltd (in liq) (1986) 4 ACLC 167Â . However, in Harpur v Ariadne Australia Ltd (1983) 8 ACLR 539Â , and on appeal Harpur v Ariadne Australia Ltd (No 2) [1984] 2 Qd R 523; (1984) 8 ACLR 835Â , it was said that the difference between the views of Street CJ and those in the cases just cited seemed to be mainly of terminology and interpretation rather than of substance. Such comments have much to commend them, especially since all the cases, including Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd (1974) 1 ACLR 301Â , affirm the proposition that the discretion to order security is to be exercised in all the circumstances of the particular case so as to attempt to achieve a balance between ensuring that protection is provided to a defendant and, on the other hand, avoiding injustice to a plaintiff by unnecessarily shutting it out or otherwise stultifying it in the conduct of litigation: see also Tradestock Pty Ltd v TNT (Management) Pty Ltd (1977) 14 ALR 52; 30 FLR 342Â in addition to the cases just cited.

level.toc-caption: [42.21.45] Enforcement of judgment — security limited to cost of

heading.title: Enforcement of judgment — security limited to cost of

p.text: Ordinarily security for costs ought not be ordered against a non-resident plaintiff if any final costs orders could be enforced by the defendant as readily as if they were orders against a resident: Connop v Varena Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 71Â ; Swain Investments Ltd v Danumet Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Cole J, No 50117/89, 5 May 1989, unreported, BC8902202); (no security against a New Zealand plaintiff) Raeburn v Andrews (1874) LR 9 QB 118; Re Howe Machine Co (1889) 41 Ch D 118Â ; Martin v McDonough (1876) 2 VLR (L) 37Â . Security may be ordered in an amount that would enable a defendant to register the Australian costs order in the plaintiff country of residence — provided that the foreign country has reciprocal enforcement arrangements with Australia: Barton v Minister for Foreign Affairs (1984) 2 FCR 463; 54 ALR 586Â ; Maxim’s Caterers LtdÂ vÂ Magnona Pty Ltd (No 1) [2010] FCA 450; BC201002924Â .
Legislation cited in [42.21.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 Ch 3.

Due to the special nature of family provision proceedings under Succession Act 2006 Ch 3 , an order for security will generally not be made against a foreign plaintiff as readily as it might be made against a foreign plaintiff in other proceedings: Singer v Berghouse (1993) 114 ALR 521; 67 ALJR 708Â per Gaudron J.

If enforcement of a foreign judgment requires some additional step before it can be enforced in the local forum, security for costs may be ordered: Kohn v Rinson & Stafford (Broad) Ltd [1948] 1 KB 327Â .

The present rule gives the court a wide discretion as to the form in which security may be given. It is common for the order to be made in terms that permit security to be provided either in cash or in some other form acceptable to a registrar of the court: see eg, Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 319 at 323Â ; Masri Apartments Pty Ltd (in liq) v Perpetual Nominees Ltd (2004) 209 ALR 86; [2004] NSWCA 255; BC200404825Â ; Patrick v Howorth [2002] NSWCA 285; BC200205001Â . Acceptable security may include an appropriately worded bank bond: see for example, Estates Property Investment Corp Ltd v Pooley (1975) 3 ACLR 256Â . If security is provided in the form of cash the court may, and usually will, require the amount of security to be held in particular account and abide further order.

The mere fact of a grant of legal aid to the plaintiff does not deprive the court of its power to make an order for security for costs: Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 443Â affirmed by the Court of Appeal Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 122Â .

Distinctions may sometimes have to be drawn between proceedings where the liquidator is a party and those where the company is the actual plaintiff. If the proceedings are of the former kind it is not usual to order security to be provided — and the liquidator will be personally liable for the costs in any event: Re Strand Wood Co Ltd [1904] 2 Ch 1Â . It may be appropriate to require security where the liquidator’s proceedings are being funded by a third person: see Green (in his capacity as liquidator of Arimco Mining Pty Ltd (in liq)) v CGU Insurance Ltd (2008) 67 ACSR 105; [2008] NSWCA 148; BC200804751 at [49]–[53]Â (liquidator suing in his own name but backed by third party litigation funder, ordered to provide security for costs). The involvement of a litigation funder is a relevant factor in deciding whether security should be ordered, however, much will depend on the terms of the funding agreement: Australian Derivatives Exchange Ltd v Doubell [2008] NSWSC 1174; BC200809833Â (agreement provided indemnity by litigation funder against costs orders made against the liquidator — this together with undertaking be liquidator to the court to pursue indemnity for the benefit of the defendants was sufficient — no security ordered). The importance of the wording of funding agreements was highlighted by the decision of the High Court in Jeffery & Katauskas Pty Ltd v SST Consulting Pty Ltd (2009) 260 ALR 34; [2009] HCA 43; BC200909275Â (funding arrangement not including an indemnity for adverse costs orders did not constitute an abuse of power for the purposes of UCPR r 42.3(2)(c) (now repealed)). This decision of the High Court is likely to encourage the application of the security for costs provisions of the UCPR when dealing with impecunious parties who have third-party litigation funding arrangements. If the company is the actual party to the proceedings, the fact that the corporation is being wound up by a court appointed liquidator would not, on its own, justify refusal of an application for security: Hession v Century 21 South Pacific Ltd (in liq) (1992) 28 NSWLR 120Â .

level.toc-caption: [42.21.75] Multiple plaintiffs — natural persons and corporations

heading.title: Multiple plaintiffs — natural persons and corporations

p.text: Where grounds for ordering security have been made out against only some of several personal plaintiffs, the ordinary principle is that security for costs will not be ordered against any of the plaintiffs. This ordinary principle reflects the entitlement of co-plaintiffs (against whom no arguable basis for security has been established) to have the matter proceed to hearing. But it assumes that the co-plaintiffs’ interests are common and that any costs orders that the defendants obtain will be enforceable against all of the co-plaintiffs: Sykes v Sykes (1869) LR 4 CP 645 at 648; McConnell v Johnston (1801) 1 East 431; 102 ER 167Â ; D’Hormusgee & Co v Grey (1882) 10 QBD 13Â . Where the co-plaintiffs include corporation(s) and natural persons and the personal plaintiff(s) are, in substance, the moving parties who are likely to suffer an order for the whole of the costs if the proceedings fail, an order for security ought not be made against the corporation(s): Harpur v Ariadne Australia Ltd (NoÂ 2) [1984] 2 Qd R 523; (1984) 8 ACLR 835Â ; Maples v Hughes [2002] NSWSC 617; BC200203814Â . But security ought be ordered if there are large areas of claim that are not common between the plaintiffs and, as a result, the personal plaintiffs are not likely to suffer an order for the whole of the costs if the proceedings fail: John Bishop (Caterers) Ltd v National Union Bank Ltd [1973] 1 All ER 707Â (Plowman J made an order for security against a plaintiff company despite the fact that there was a natural person who was a co-plaintiff). Consequently it may be particularly appropriate to order security against a corporate co-plaintiff where it is apparent that the natural person co-plaintiff’s interests are either insubstantial or materially different from those of the corporate plaintiff: Pearson v Naydler [1977] 3 All ER 531; [1977] 1 WLR 899Â ; Interwest Ltd v Tricontinental Corp Ltd (1991) 5 ACSR 621Â ; Electrona Carbide Industries Pty Ltd v Tasmanian Govt Insurance Board (1985) 3Â ACLC 702; Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2004) 208 ALR 564; [2004] NSWSC 664; BC200404777 at [68]–[71]Â ; Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1317; BC200610115 at [27]–[36]Â (order for security against corporate plaintiff — plaintiffs relied on similar facts, but relied on different causes of action).
Evidence of an offer of compromise is not admissible on an application for security for costs: Macplan Logistic Systems Pty Ltd v Baxter Healthcare Pty Ltd (1996) 39 NSWLR 324Â .

A party who is merely a nominal plaintiff may be ordered to provide security under this rule: Riot Nominees Pty Ltd v Suzuki Australia Pty Ltd (1981) 34 ALR 653Â . But the court must first be satisfied, on the balance of probabilities, that the plaintiff is bringing the proceedings for the benefit of some other person: Johnson v Lake Macquarie City Council (1995) 87 LGERA 22Â . And a party who can demonstrate a real interest in the proceedings will not be required to provide security even if the “real interest” does not constitute a direct pecuniary interest in the outcome of the proceedings: Andrews v Caltex Pty Ltd (1982) 40 ALR 305Â . For the purposes of r 42.21(2)(e) “benefit” has a wide meaning and its application depends on the circumstances of each case. Ordinarily persons who are suing in a representative capacity such as a trustee in bankruptcy: Cowell v Taylor (1885) 31 Ch D 34 at 38Â ; a liquidator: Re Strand Wood Co Ltd [1904] 2 Ch 1Â ; an administrator: Rainbow v Kitto [1916] 1 Ch 313Â ; or a trustee: White v Butt [1909] 1 KB 50Â ; Riot Nominees Pty Ltd v Suzuki Australia Pty Ltd (1981) 34 ALR 653Â ; (but compare Greener v Kahn & Co [1906] 2 KB 374Â ); will be personally liable for the costs of unsuccessful proceedings and, accordingly, they ought not to be required to provide security for costs. Similarly the fact that the members of an unincorporated association would benefit from the successful outcome of the proceedings brought by the association does not, without more, necessarily indicate that the association is suing for the benefit of another person: Byron Shire Business for the Future Inc v Byron Shire Council and Holiday Villages (Byron Bay) Pty Ltd (1994) 83 LGERA 59Â . On the other hand, security may properly be ordered where the plaintiff has assigned the benefit of the cause of action: Semler v Murphy [1968] Ch 183Â ; unless the assignment is only as to part of the proceeds of the cause of action and the plaintiff retains a significant pecuniary interest in the outcome of the litigation: Ramsey v Hartley [1977] 2 All ER 673; [1977] 1 WLR 686Â .

level.toc-caption: [42.21.90] Parties against whom an order may be made

heading.title: Parties against whom an order may be made

p.text: An order for security for costs can be made against any party who makes a claim for relief in the proceedings. It follows that under this Part “plaintiff” is not used with any restricted technical meaning: Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd (1974) 1 ACLR 301 at 306–7Â . Thus the expression includes an appellant: Re Photographic Artists' Co-op Supply Assn (1883) 23 Ch D 370Â and also a cross-claimant in cases where the cross-claim is not merely a defence to the action: Bevwizz Group Pty Ltd v Transport Solutions Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1399; BC200812484Â (defensive cross-claim — order refused). At its widest it includes any person who is seeking to enforce any right in the proceedings: Crystal Theatres Ltd v Fuss (1940) 57 WN (NSW) 107 at 108Â . But that wide proposition requires qualification. First of all, a party’s formal status as “plaintiff” will not suffice to justify a security for costs order if the practical reality is that the litigation has been initiated by the conduct of the nominal defendant: Willey v Synan (1935) 54 CLR 175; [1936] ALR 1Â ; Re Travel Lodge Australia Ltd (1978) 21 ACTR 17Â ; Amalgamated Mining Services Pty Ltd v Warman International Ltd (1988) 19 FCR 324Â . Secondly, a defendant cannot normally be regarded as a “plaintiff”: Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd, above, at 307; Washoe Mining Co v Ferguson (1866) LR 2 Eq 371; Neck v Taylor [1893] 1 QB 560Â ; New Fenix Co v General Accident Corp [1911] 2 KB 619Â . Consequently, a defendant/cross-claimant who is, in substance, merely defending a claim, is not a “plaintiff” for the purposes of the present rule and cannot be ordered to provide security — unless the defence includes some separate claim Stanley-Hill v Kool [1982] 1 NSWLR 460 at 464Â ; Putney Group Pty Ltd v Royal Rehabilitation Centre Sydney [2009] NSWSC 424; BC200904490Â (cross-claim and claim partly overlapping — order made for security of costs); Bevwizz Group Pty Ltd v Transport Solutions Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1399; BC200812484Â (defensive cross-claim — order refused); KDL Building v Mount [2006] NSWSC 474; BC200604389Â (partly overlapping issues on claim and cross claim — order for security on discrete claim issues — partial order on overlapping issues)). This is so even if the defendant initiates an interlocutory application: Re B [1965] 2 All ER 651 at 652; [1965] 1 WLR 946 at 948Â . However, security for costs have been ordered against a defendant in proceedings brought to set aside a statutory demand: Classic Ceramic Importers Pty Ltd v Ceramica Antiga SA (1994) 13 ACSR 263Â . The order was made on the basis that the defendant, as the creditor, was the "aggressor" party: D S Parklane Developments Pty Ltd v Korea First Finance Ltd (NSWSC, Santow J, 20Â August 1997, BC9703785).

level.toc-caption: [42.21.95] Plaintiffs ordinarily resident outside the State

heading.title: Plaintiffs ordinarily resident outside the State

p.text: Section 117 of the Constitution precludes an order for security for costs being made against an individual plaintiff who is ordinarily resident in another state of Australia: Australian Building Construction Employees’ and Builders’ Labourers’ Federation v Commonwealth Trading Bank [1976] 2 NSWLR 371Â ; Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd v ARM Equipment Finance Pty Ltd (2001) 159 FLR 310; [2001] NSWSC 28; BC200100087 at [55], [56]Â ; compare Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 443 at 451Â . Nevertheless, r 42.21(a) may still apply to persons who reside outside Australia and to other (non-natural) legal entities that do not constitute “subjects” of the Queen: see Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd, above, at [51]; Mothership Music Pty Ltd vÂ Flo Rida (aka Tramar Dillard) [2012] NSWCA 344; BC201208840Â (resident outside Australia).

level.toc-caption: [42.21.97] Litigants in person and security for costs

heading.title: Litigants in person and security for costs

p.text: An order for security will be of practically no benefit to defendants who are not represented — because unrepresented litigants can only recover out-of-pocket expenses. But it may be relevant to consider whether a litigant intends to obtain representation, and whether an order for security might assist their prospects of obtaining representation: IceTV Pty Ltd v Ross [2007] NSWSC 1232; BC200709455Â (order for security for costs made — defendants not represented at security hearing, but previously represented at interlocutory hearing — “manifest from the substance of their evidence that they wish to be represented, if they can afford it”).

An application for security for costs should be made promptly and before the plaintiff has embarked on the litigation to any real extent: Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd (1974) 1 ACLR 301 at 309Â ; Smail v Burton [1975] VR 776; (1975) 1 ACLR 75Â ; Foss Export Agency Pty Ltd v Trotman (1949) 67 WN (NSW) 1Â ; Gabel Pty Ltd v Katherine Enterprises Pty Ltd (1977) 2 ACLR 400Â . However, delays are not an automatic bar to the making of the order for security for costs: Commonwealth v Cable Water Skiing (Aust) Ltd (1994) 14 ACSR 760Â (delay of over 4 years after proceedings had been commenced). The court is entitled to have regard to the length of the delay, the reasons for it, the nature of the acts done during the intervening period and whether security is sought both for future costs and those which have already been incurred: Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 114Â . An instance of a successful application made after the commencement of the hearing can be found in Estates Property Investment Corp Ltd v Pooley (1975) 3 ACLR 256Â . But significant, unexplained delay by a defendant aware of the probable impecuniosity of the plaintiff can ordinarily be expected to result in the refusal of an application for security costs: Morris v Hanley [2001] NSWCA 374; BC200106752Â ; Thalanga Copper Mines Pty Ltd v Brandrill Ltd [2004] NSWSC 349; BC200404993Â ; Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Narui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 563; BC200905277Â (application made just prior to seventh anniversary of proceedings — application refused, but discussion of supervening event — ie recent loss of indemnity and insolvency of entity offering indemnity).

Applications for security should be made reasonably promptly after the commencement of the proceedings. A corollary of that requirement is that the court will be reluctant to order security for costs that have already been incurred: G Dal Pont, Law of Costs, Australia, Butterworths, 2003 at [28.35]; see also Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 114Â (security application made after 65 hearing days – security refused for past costs); Citrus Queensland Pty Ltd v Sunstate Orchards Pty Ltd (No 5) [2006] FCA 1672; BC200610092Â (security application 10 days into trial hearing — unacceptable delay — application refused); Sagacious Procurement Pty Ltd v Symbion Health Ltd [2007] NSWCA 205; BC200706645Â (security granted for appeal but not for the costs of the first instance proceedings). Security cannot be effectively ordered after the proceedings have been heard: Sagacious Procurement Pty Ltd v Symbion Health Ltd , above, at [55] (to make such an order is tantamount to “securing the stable door after the horse has bolted”). If the application is made promptly, security may include both past and future costs: Brocklebank & Co v The King’s Lynn Steamship Co (1878) 3 CPD 365Â (plaintiff became bankrupt after commencement of the proceedings); Massey v Allen (1879) 12 ChD 807; JWH Turner & Co Ltd v O’Riordan (1923) 40 WN (NSW) 64Â ; Harvey v Jacob (1817) 106 ER 59Â ; Bryan E Fencott and Associates Pty Ltd v Eretta Pty Ltd (1987) 16 FCR 497Â .

It is not uncommon for a trading company to act merely as a trustee, particularly in the case of family trusts. In such instances, the company itself will have only nominal assets with the bulk of the property to which it is legally entitled being held by it as trustee. Where an application for security is made against such a company, however, it will be proper to take into account the trustee's right of indemnity against the trust property: see generally Octavo Investments Pty Ltd v Knight (1979) 144 CLR 360 at 367; 27 ALR 129; BC7900099 Â , and also Ford and Lee, Principles of the Law of Trusts at [1403], Jacobs, Law of Trusts in Australia 4th ed at [2102]. In Bell Wholesale Co v Gates Export Corp (1983) 2Â FCR 1; 52 ALR 176, an order for security was made against a trustee corporation, while in Marson Pty Ltd v Pressbank Pty Ltd (1983) 7Â ACLR 905 the application for security was refused. In Memutu Pty Ltd v Lissenden (1983) 8Â ACLR 364 no order for security was made but a third party who was a beneficiary under the trust undertook to make his personal assets available to meet any order for costs that might be made. In Tranocean Capital Pty Ltd v AFSIG Pty Ltd (2006) 202 FLR 270; [2006] NSWSC 806; BC200606178Â , it was established that the plaintiff trustee was likely to be unable to pay the defendant’s costs if they were successful in their defence. As a separate question Barret J determined that the discretion to order security should be exercised (at [41]).

Under r 41.21(3) , the court may dismiss proceedings where a plaintiff fails to comply with an order to provide security. Exercise of the power to dismiss requires consideration of a number of factors, including: (i) the time that has passed since security was ordered; (ii) the plaintiff’s likely ability to provide security; (iii) the extent to which the plaintiff has been on notice of the dismissal application; (iv) the likelihood of prejudice to the defendant (as a result of continuing the stay); (v) the impact on the court of continuing the stay; (vi) the ability of the plaintiff to commence new proceedings (see CPA s 91 , r 12.10 and [12.7.40] ); and (vii) prejudice to the plaintiff (eg, as a result of the expiry of a relevant limitation period): Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2002] NSWCA 271; BC200204579Â ; Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd (No 3) [2005] NSWCA 377; BC200509277Â ; Battenberg v Union Club [2007] NSWSC 265; BC200701986Â (proceedings on foot for 2 years, no explanation for non-compliance with order for security, no evidence of intention to comply, bankruptcy — proceedings dismissed); Owners of Strata Plan 61732 Pty Ltd v TR Druce Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1024; BC200908822 at [28]Â (cross-claim dismissed — no explanation for failure to provide security). If a significant sum has been ordered for security, and a plaintiff with due notice of the dismissal application fails to satisfy the court that there is any prospect of complying with the order, the proceedings should ordinarily be dismissed: Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd (No 3) , above.

The present rule does not affect the provisions of any other statutory power under which the court may require security for costs. CPA sÂ 67 confers a general power to stay proceedings. In appropriate cases that power may be exercised on terms that have the practical effect of requiring a party to provide security: Phillips Electronics Australia PtyÂ Ltd v Matthews (2002) 54 NSWLR 598; [2002] NSWCA 157; BC200202749Â . An appropriate occasion for the exercise of that power may arise where a plaintiff is in default of orders made in proceedings in another court or jurisdiction (and which therefore fall outside the specific provisions of UCPR rÂ 12.10 ): Byrnes v John Fairfax Publications PtyÂ Ltd [2006] NSWSC 251; BC200602077 atÂ [33]–[36]Â ; Duynstee v Dickins [2011] NSWSC 408; BC201103373Â (application for leave to appeal — untimely evidence in Local Court proceedings — refusal of extension — substantial unpaid costs in other proceedings — security ordered).
